finding: The SNP rs13040713 was associated with epigenetic alterations in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). This finding emerged from the research that focused on the critical role of extracellular matrix in TNBC, highlighting how genetic variations such as this SNP can influence the disease's progression and response to treatments like eribulin.
title: Alteration of DNMT1/DNMT3A by eribulin elicits global DNA methylation changes with potential therapeutic implications for triple-negative breast cancer

finding: The SNP rs191830490 was associated with the HNF4A locus and indicated potential shared effects between liver (TOA=0.40) and islet (TOA=0.31) tissues.
title: A multi-omic integrative scheme characterizes tissues of action at loci associated with type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs76811102 was linked to the HNF4A locus, showing a maximum TOA score of 0.32 for islet and lower scores for muscle (TOA=0.25) and liver (TOA=0.24), suggesting a possible regulatory role.
title: A multi-omic integrative scheme characterizes tissues of action at loci associated with type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs143383 was identified as a susceptibility marker for osteoarthritis by influencing the regulation of GDF5 expression through trans-acting factors. This finding highlighted the importance of this specific SNP in the context of osteoarthritis susceptibility.
title: NERD-seq: A novel approach of Nanopore direct RNA sequencing that expands representation of non-coding RNAs

finding: The MMP-9 polymorphism rs17576 was correlated with susceptibility to type 2 diabetes, suggesting a role in the pathophysiology of the disease.
title: Identification of Key Genes and Underlying Mechanisms in Cystic Fibrosis and its Associated Complications Based on Bioinformatics Analysis of Next Generation Sequencing Data Analysis

finding: The SNP rs3746444 was found to be associated with breast cancer risk in the Iranian population, highlighting its potential relevance in disease susceptibility studies.
title: Circulating MicroRNAs indicative of sex and stress in the European seabass (Dicentrarchus labrax): toward the identification of new biomarkers

finding: The CHRNA4 gene polymorphism rs1044396 was linked to Parkinson's disease symptoms and smoking behavior.
title: Identification of key genes and signaling pathway in the pathogenesis of Huntington’s disease via bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The CHRNA4 gene variant rs1044397 was also associated with Parkinson's disease, underscoring its role in neurodegenerative conditions.
title: Identification of key genes and signaling pathway in the pathogenesis of Huntington’s disease via bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The study performed a GWAS analysis focusing on the phenotype 'CaffeineConsumption'. It calculated p-values between case samples (CaffeineConsumption > 4) and control samples (CaffeineConsumption ≤ 4) specifically for rs6053810. The results indicated a significant association between rs6053810 and caffeine consumption based on this analysis, underlining its role in caffeine-related phenotypes.
title: Towards a new standard in genomic data privacy: a realization of owner-governance

finding: The variant rs6031615 was associated with Epstein-Barr virus-encoded RNAs, which were identified as critical factors in viral pathogenesis, affecting type I interferon pathways in infected human cells.
title: Multiple viral microRNAs regulate interferon release and signaling early during infection with Epstein-Barr virus

finding: The SNP rs2281285 within PDYN was linked to alcohol dependence and drinking behavior in negative emotional states; multiple studies indicated its association with alcohol-related traits.
title: Genome-wide association mapping of ethanol sensitivity in the Diversity Outbred mouse population

finding: The SNP rs13042395 was identified as a biomarker for regional lymph node metastasis and relapse-free survival in patients with esophageal squamous cell carcinoma. This finding was significant as it helped to establish a connection between the genetic variation in the SLC52A3 gene and the prognosis of cancer progression, particularly in relation to lymphatic involvement.
title: Identification of key genes and associated pathways in neuroendocrine tumors through bioinformatics analysis and predictions of small drug molecules

finding: The SNP rs6043852 was associated with MUC5B concentration due to joint SNP and smoking interactions, although the significance must be interpreted with caution due to low sample size.
title: Genetic Regulators of Sputum Mucin Concentration and Their Associations with COPD Phenotypes

finding: The SNP rs13040725 was associated with the regulation of cofilin-1 in pancreatic cancer, indicating its potential role in tumor promotion and cancer progression. This finding highlighted the significance of genetic variations in influencing tumor biology and differentiation processes.
title: Data-driven inference of Boolean networks from transcriptomes to predict cellular differentiation and reprogramming

finding: The SNP rs6031769 was found to be positively correlated with drug resistance in cancer, indicating that it could influence multiple traits related to cancer progression and treatment responses. This finding contributed to an understanding of genetic factors that affect therapeutic outcomes in oncology, suggesting a potential role of this SNP in phenotypic variation associated with cancer.
title: Extent and context dependence of pleiotropy revealed by high-throughput single-cell phenotyping

finding: The SNP rs6042155 was associated with viral carcinogenesis, specifically in the context of HPV integration and its effects on genomic stability in oropharyngeal squamous carcinomas (OPSCC). The research indicated a link between the genotype at this SNP and the risk of developing tumors, as HPV-positive OPSCC cases with integrated viral genomes exhibited different outcomes compared to those with episomal genomes. This highlights the relevance of rs6042155 in understanding the biological mechanisms behind HPV-related oncogenesis and genomic instability.
title: Genome Instability Precedes Viral Integration in Human Papilloma Virus Transformed Tonsillar Keratinocytes

finding: The SNP rs6031769 was associated with mutations that confer resistance to targeted cancer therapies. It was found that this mutation had been previously validated and was predicted to have immunogenic potential, suggesting that its associated neopeptides could elicit T-cell responses in vitro. This finding contributed to the broader understanding of how resistance mutations can serve as potential therapeutic targets in immunotherapy.
title: The immunogenic potential of recurrent cancer drug resistance mutations: an in silico study

finding: The SNP rs8121031 was associated with phenotypic traits such as plant height and growth rate in winter wheat (Triticum aestivum L.). In the context of the study, it was determined that specific genotypes carrying this SNP displayed greater phenotypic plasticity, which contributed to dominant yield performance in mixed stands as oppose to their behavior in pure stands.
title: Contrasted phenotypic plasticities of life-history traits in interacting plants: case of pure versus mixed stands of wheat

finding: The SNP rs4810485 was associated with both alternative splicing of CD40 transcripts and lower levels of the anti-inflammatory cytokine IL-10 in peripheral blood among individuals with Multiple Sclerosis (MS) and healthy controls. Specifically, this variant correlated with a relative upregulation of the splice isoform of CD40 that lacks exon 5, resulting in decreased cell-surface expression of the CD40 protein. This genetic modulation of CD40 mRNA expression was suggested to contribute to increased MS risk through its effects on IL-10 production, although the precise mechanism was yet to be clarified.
title: Summary-data-based mendelian randomisation reveals druggable targets for multiple sclerosis

finding: The SNP rs13040918 was associated with plasticity in colorectal cancer as detailed in a study by Walter et al. (2021). This finding indicated a correlation between genetic variations at this locus and the ability of cancer cells to differentiate, impacting the responsiveness to targeted therapies in colorectal cancer.
title: Functional and spatial proteomics profiling reveals intra- and intercellular signaling crosstalk in colorectal cancer
